A convenient way to picture a full-flow engine is by looking at a turbojet engine. In a turbojet, the air is pulled into a compressor, which in the burner is mixed with a little bit of fuel, expanded and pressurized, and escapes out the back through a turbine that extracts enough energy to power the compressor, and shoots the rest out the tailpipe. The output is mostly normal air, with a little combustion exhaust.

A full flow preburner rocket engine is like having two turbojets, one flowing oxygen and a little fuel, and the other flowing fuel and a little oxygen, with both turbojet engines feeding the combustion chamber their exhausts.

When they do a "spin test", they're running one or other of the jet engines for a moment.

There's actually one more cycle: the one used on the Black Arrow. Here, the oxidizer - hydrogen peroxide - is used as a monopropellant to run the turbopumps, and then the decomposition products, which happen to be hypergolic with RP-1, are used as the actual oxidizer in the main combustion chamber. The same thing can probably be done with hydrazine and N2O4, just with the roles reversed.

I was beginning to worry that you wouldn't talk about the RL-10. If memory serves (and I'm 84 now so who knows) the RL-10 used a bootstrap start where the liquid hydrogen was used to "prime" the engine such that when it was needed to actually ignite and provide thrust, a frangible disk valve was pierced. The liquid hydrogen immediately flashed to gas which then "powered" the turbo pump to pump the lox and more hydrogen into the engine. When the correct condition was achieved the engine was lit and the process continued until engine was shut down. Obviously an oversimplification but should begin to illustrate the RL-10's somewhat novel design.

There is the pressure-fed engines that HAD to fly untested, and fire the first time, every time; the LEM's Descent and Ascent engines, designed by TRW and Rocketdyne, respectively.  The Descent engine could also throttle, and designed to crush on landing, acting as a shock absorber, as was demonstrated on Apollo 15.  These engines were installed UNTESTED into the LEM as it was a complex act to clean and refurbish them after testing as they operated on helium-pressured hypergolics.  So they were designed with super simplicity in mind and put to the test.  And you guessed it, they flew without a hitch and were the unsung heroes of Apollo.

After watching this for the first time, I was very confused as to how the gas-driven pumps work. Watching a second time, it seems like this vid doesn't really address it, but I had some thoughts of my own, so I'm going to put them here and hope Everyday Astronaut or another informed person can weigh in.

The initial confusion comes from the fact that due to the pressure gradients needed to make sure fuel and oxidizer flow in the correct direction, the gas driving the pump would be at a lower pressure than the output pressure of the pump. This struck me as unphysical and like a recipe for a perpetual motion machine -- connect the pump output to the gas input.

However, I realized that a pump could use mechanical advantage to allow the lower pressure gas input to create a higher pressure output -- but at the cost of needing a greater volume rate of flow in the gas input than the pump output will have. No perpetual motion machine possible. That greater volume of gas is available since when the liquid propellants become gaseous, the same amount of propellant at a given pressure occupies a much greater volume. Is this how the pumps work?

@48:50 I was confused about why it's easier to cool a larger engine until I realized that the amount of fuel used (I presume) scales as the volume of the engine. So with larger engines the amount of fuel per cooling surface area increases.

But OTOH, the amount of heat generated should also scale with the volume (and the amount of fuel) so again it's not clear why cooling a larger engine is easier. The lower surface to volume ratio of larger engines is generally working against you cooling-wise. For extremely large (perhaps impractically large) engines the amount of surface area is negligible compared to the volume while the larger amount of fuel flowing through the walls should be exactly offset by the larger amount of heat that fuel generates.

Enthalpy = internal energy + pressure x volume. Why is pressure x volume the same as energy? Internal energy is measured in Newton.Meters (Joules). Pressure is measured in Newtons/meter^2. Volume is measured in meter^3. So Enthalpy = Newton.meters + Newton.meters.... so yes, Enthalpy is measured in Newton.meters (energy)!

The actual thrust equations for the operation in space is
Tr = mdot × Vex
mdot = total mass flow rate
Vex = exhaust velocity, mean
depending on the area ratio: nozzle area to throat area , a residual pressure pn remains, a further lateral expansion occurs, called the Prandtl-Meyer corner expansion, not producing any thrust, but visible .
at the throat, the velocity is equal to the local speed of sound, which is for non diassociated gas
a = sqrt(gam× R/Mix × Temp)
gam is the ratio of specific heats
about 1.31 for the co2, h2o
mixture
R is the Gasconstant = 8.3144 ( kJ/ mole Kelvin)
Mmix = is the average molecular weight for the gas mixture (kg/mole) = ~27
Temp, the gas temp at the throat.
When the pressure at the Nozzle is known and so the chamber pressure pc and temperature after combustion Tc, the temperature at the nozzle is
Tn =~ Tc × (pn/pc)^[(gam-1)/gam]
then, finally, the exhaust velocity
Vex = sqrt(2× [Tc - Tn]×cp )
cp = R/Mix × gam/(gam-1)
[Tc - Tn ]× cp is the specific enthalpy change realized.
The exhaust pressure can be calculated by the max observed deflection angle of the nozzle rim Prandl - Meyer expansion into a vacuum
The specific impulse is Vex/g
g = 9.80665 m/s²

Great video! The only thing I'd add is that the choice between a fuel rich or oxygen rich closed cycle is not based on corrosion or coking. It is based on the chemistry of the propellants you choose. For instance, A Methalox engine uses the chemical equation CH4 + 2O2 -> CO2 + 2H2O. For our reactants 2/3 of the moles (and hence volumetric flow and hence ability to do work) is in the Oxygen. Therefore you use an oxygen rich preburner closed cycle. A Hydrolox engine uses the chemical equation 2H2 + O2 -> 2H2O. Now the fuel is 2/3 of the propellant flow by volume so a fuel rich preburner would be chosen instead.

Also, since temperature is proportional to the kinetic energy of the molecules (=1/2 M V2), the lighter the molecular mass of the reacted products, the higher the specific impulse for a given chamber temperature. The higher the pressure of the chamber, the more of that potential to do work can be extracted (to the point where the fuel starts to turn back into a liquid as you covered already).

I had to listen to the description of the expander cycle a couple times, but I think I get it. It sounds impossible: fuel first flows from low pressure to high. So far so good, because it does so under the influence of a pump. Then the same fuel goes from high pressure to medium, driving a turbine -- the same turbine that powers the pump, not only for the fuel but also the O2. Less mass-per-second of material going through less of a pressure drop, to power more mass-per-second going through more of a pressure increase? That's what sounds impossible. But power isn't mass per second times pressure difference. It's volume per second times pressure difference. A smaller volume of cold fuel gets pumped, and then turns into a larger volume of hot fuel as it goes through the regenerative cooling system.

It seems as though you could sort-of get around the size limit by having one turbine drive one pair of pumps to feed one combustion chamber, and then get enough area for heat exchange by having it go through multiple nozzles. But I don't know where the benefits of having a larger engine show up. Maybe it's all from a larger nozzle, in which case you wouldn't gain anything by having the nozzles technically be part of the same engine.

What if you stored your methane and oxygen as solids in your tanks? As you froze the fuel/oxidizer in your tanks spin the tanks in centrifuges to create a channel down the middle. Well insulated tanks would leave the central channel as the only free surface. The pressure tank walls would be very thick due to the solid fuel/oxidizer and could therefore hold that central channel to high pressures. Each tank would only need a regulator feeding the combustion chamber.

There is one more engine cycle variant not shown here, but that has actually flown!
If one of your bipropellants is itself a monopropellant, you can use its decomposition to power the turbomachinery and then combustion those reaction products in the MCC, for a fully closed cycle without any preburners and without the thermal limits of an expander cycle. I guess you could call this a "staged decomposition cycle".
The Bristol Siddeley Gamma is an example of this, where the Hydrogen Peroxide oxidiser was decomposed to power the turbopumps and then the hot decomposition products (water and H2, plus some unreacted H2O2) burnt in the combustion chamber. Which also had the side benefit of igniting hypergolicly without needing to carry any hypergols!

Loved the video, but AFAIK there are errors in the way entropy is described. High entropy does not mean high temperature, but low amount of energy that can be put at work. Considering heat only, whatever the temperature, if everything in the system has the same temp, then entropy is at its highest and no energy can be harnessed. If your system has regions having high temp difference between them, then you have low entropy and can put that temperature gradient at work. In a closed isolated system, entropy can only increase, which means the amount of available energy to be put at work can only decrease.

Rocket Engine 101

You describe hydrogen peroxide as a “strong reducing agent”. It is actually an oxidizer. Hydrazine happens to be a reducing agent. But in both cases these properties are quite irrelevant to the operation of the engine as they do not get to participate in any oxidation/reduction reaction - their decomposition products are simply released through the nozzle.
The important property is that these chemicals have a positive enthalpy of formation i.e. their decomposition is exothermic. Such chemicals are, by definition, unstable. Especially at high concentrations used for rockets. Ideally, they would be reasonably stable in storage and only decompose where and when you want them to.

13:21 in video: You state that tanks can be thinner. NOT SO. In pressure-fed monopropellent or bipropellent, the fuel tank & the pressurizing gas tank MUST be at "crazy high pressure" (higher than the combustion or reaction chamber), just like the cold gas thruster. The ONLY advantage is the propellant expanding after the reaction. So volume rate increases, but THE PRESSURES ARE THE SAME, & the tank walls must be JUST AS THICK & HEAVY for a given combustion or reaction chamber pressure & volume for combined fuel & gas.
You also fail to mention that there needs to be a way to keep the pressurizing gas separated from the fuel (either a membrane or using G-field & density difference between fuel & pressurizing gas).

This is how you understand rocket science.   A lot of people don’t understand that it’s the pumps that usually define the rocket engine not the nozzles.  The largest Russian rocket engines had 2 and even 4 nozzles for the turbo pumps, so they were considered one engine.  Large combustion chambers can suffer from combustion instability, like what plagued the F-1 on the Saturn V.  So instead of one large combustion camber just make 2 or 4 smaller ones that don’t have combustion instability.  That is why it is the pumps that define the rocket engine not the combustion chamber. The volume of flow and pressures these pumps produce is mind boggling.

As always an awesome video for anyone to learn how rocket engines work. Would like to add some extra details on turbine design for the turbo pump. As you have beautifully mentioned that staged combustion cycle require more mass flow in pre burner than in gas generator, the turbine type called as  “reaction turbine” is used which allows less pressure drop in turbine and the flow through turbine is subsonic and is achieved by a subsonic nozzle upstream of turbine. Whereas in gas generator cycle since the flow is not coupled with chamber, we can afford a huge pressure drop in turbine/nozzle of turbine. This case requires another type of turbine called an “Impulse turbine” which works on momentum transfer principle. All the flow is expanded in a de laval nozzle just before turbine which creates a supersonic flow. Pressure drop in turbine section is negligible. The amount of gas expanded in turbine section compared to total expansion in nozzle and turbine is called as degree of reaction. Reaction turbine has high degree of reaction and the shape of blades is similar to an airfoil. Impulse turbine has very low degree of reaction and the design of blade is very simple.

small correction. helium is not used in cold gas thrusters because of its low molecular weight. sure, it technically comes out faster, but because it's so light, it's depleted way too quickly. you have this big heavy pressurized tank just to store a tiny amount of helium. so instead, heavier gases like nitrogen are used (kinda like how water is used in water rockets, instead of only air). yes, helium is used to push fuel and oxidizer into the combustion chamber, but never as a cold gas thruster.

If you want a bigger expander cycle engine and you don't want to mess with high surface-area altitude-compensating nozzles or crazy chamber geometries with whacked-out fluid dynamics, why not just do what Russian engineers did since forever ago (RD-200?) and add more chambers? Rockets don't have a horsepower.  Just a thrust.  That is to say, power being thrust times speed, you get any horsepower you want as you go faster.  Conventional engines lose thrust as speed increases beyond a certain point so they have a (peak) power.  Rockets don't.

You made a mistake at 5:00 when making the absolute statement "always flows from high to low (pressure)". In actuality, pressure is just one term on the right of the Navier-Stokes equation.

On the right side, there are other forces which can direct flow, including body forces (e.g. due to an acceleration or a force field in the case of magnetohydrodynamics) and viscous forces.

Also a part of Navier-Stokes equation is momentum. An object stays in motion unless acted on by a net force, at which point it accelerates. A flow could continue up an adverse pressure gradient for a while, given it starts with some non-zero momentum. It takes force x time to change a fluid's momentum.

It is a common misconception even amongst Youtube experts that "fluid always flows from high to low pressure". TechIngredients made the same mistake. It's simply a fallacy.
